item.title: Is WiMAX Worth the Wait?
item.description:
For years, the arrival of WiMAX, a new wireless broadband standard, has been highly anticipated. From its conceptual phase to the development of standards, equipment certification, and the launch of pilot projects, the journey of WiMAX has been closely followed. However, with its impending arrival, the question arises: will WiMAX still live up to its initial hype? WiMAX, short for Worldwide Interoperability for Microwave Access, is a globally recognized standard with potential applications in various fields such as cellular backhaul, mobile internet, business broadband, and even as a potential replacement for WiFi...
Read The Full Article :https://Nexus-Security.github.io/is-wimax-worth-the-wait/

item.title: 10 Mbps Up and Down
item.description:
It’s been said that 10 Mbps is the new standard for business bandwidth, similar to how the T1 line (1.5 Mbps) was once considered the benchmark. This shift towards higher bandwidth is driven by the increasing demands of modern business applications. T1 lines gained popularity as the internet became a vital business tool in the 1990s. They offered sufficient speed and were readily available. However, the internet has evolved significantly since then...
Read The Full Article :https://Nexus-Security.github.io/10-mbps-up-and-down/

item.title: Bandwidth Deals for MSPs
item.description:
Managed Service Providers (MSPs) can provide more value to their clients by helping them find better deals on WAN bandwidth, in addition to their existing IT services. Many companies are unaware of the changes in the telecommunications market and the cheaper options now available. A basic bandwidth service that businesses should consider is T1, which offers reliable voice and/or data services with a service level agreement. T1 prices have significantly decreased this decade, often by 50% or even 67%...
Read The Full Article :https://Nexus-Security.github.io/bandwidth-deals-for-msps/

item.title: Technologies That Should Stay in 2012
item.description:
While technological advancements are incremental, they often force us to upgrade to the latest devices while clinging to older ones for compatibility. Eventually, the old tech fades away, replaced by the new, only for the cycle to repeat itself. Let’s explore some technologies that are nearing obsolescence. Analog phone systems are on the verge of disappearing. Their outdated features, lack of mobile compatibility, and proprietary wiring make them impractical. While analog lines offer clear voice quality and affordability for small businesses, their lack of mobility is a dealbreaker...
Read The Full Article :https://Nexus-Security.github.io/technologies-that-should-stay-in-2012/
